content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select two true statements about the graph that represents \(y=2x(x-11)\).

Correct! Its \(x\)-intercepts are at (0,0) and (11,0).The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: Its \(x\)-intercepts are at (0,0) and (11,0). The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two equations whose graphs have a vertex with \(x\)-coordinate 2.

Correct! \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\) and \( y=x(x-4)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: Its \(x\)-intercepts are \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\), \(y=x(x-4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Three different equations are given. Refer to these equations to complete questions a–f.

Equation

\(x\)-intercepts

\(x\)-coordinate of the vertex

\(y=x(x-2)\)

a. _____

b. _____

\(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)

c. _____

d. _____

\(y=-5x(3-x)\)

e. _____

f. _____

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)?

Correct! \((0,0)\) and \((2,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((0,0)\) and \((2,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?

Correct! \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -0.5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -0.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?

Correct! \((0,0)\) and \((3,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(0,0)\) and \((3,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1.5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer questions a–c about the function \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\).

Correct! \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Is \((-1,3)\) a point on the graph?

Correct! Substituting -1 for \(x\) gives \((-1-2)(-1-4)\) or -3 -5, which is 15, so \((-1,15)\) would be a point on the graph, not \((-1,3)\).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.11.2 and 7.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. Substituting -1 for \(x\) gives \((-1-2)(-1-4)\) or \(-3 \cdot  -5\), which is 15, so \((-1,15)\) would be a point on the graph, not \((-1,3)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Does the graph represent the equation \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.11.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

YThe correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
